# Genetic Mechanisms

## Proteins

The proteins comprising an animal's body are essential material to all behavioral phenotypes. Proteins provide the physical form of an animal, which grants unique affordances to different animals. Proteins also dictate the functional properties of an animal's nervous system, which orchestrates the actions of behavior directly. 


:::{figure-md} gif
:class: figure

<img src="/images/large_subunit.gif" alt="fishy" width="200px">

An example protein animated in 3-D (a large ribosomal subunit). Ribosomes "build" proteins. Gif from [PDB-101](https://pdb101.rcsb.org/learn/videos/ribosomal-subunits)
:::

:::{figure-md} ach-receptor
:class: figure

<img src="/images/71-AcetylcholineReceptor-2bg9-composite.png" alt="fishy" width="200px">

An example protein - the acetylcholine receptor. This protein is found in muscle cells and is necessary for muscle contraction in response to synaptic input from motor neurons. When acetylcholine binds to the receptor, the receptor lets specific ions through the membrane. Top: side view with cell membrane in gray. Bottom: top view with acetylcholine binding sites in red. Image from [PDB-101](https://pdb101.rcsb.org/motm/71)
:::

***Q: Think back to the "[neural mechanisms](../levels-of-analysis/neural/#table1)" work you have done. What ions do you think the acetylcholine receptor lets through the membrane when bound by acetylcholine?***

All proteins are comprised of amino acids, molecules that share a common structure as seen in Fig. ____.

:::{figure-md} amino-acids
:class: figure

<img src="/images/AminoAcids.png" alt="fishy" width="500px">

Common amino acids. Image from [ReAgent](https://www.reagent.co.uk/what-are-amino-acids/)
:::

***Q: Write out the single-letter code for the protein sequence: Methionine-Glutamic acid-Proline-Tryptophan.***

## Central Dogma

Examine the following deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA), ribonucleic acid (RNA), and amino acid (AA) sequences from the [NCBI GenBank](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/193788647). Each letter represents an individual molecule. 

:::{dropdown} The *gene* for the acetylcholine receptor alpha-1 subunit (length 1449 characters)

:::

:::{dropdown} The *transcribed* mRNA for the acetylcholine receptor alpha-1 subunit (length 1449 characters)

:::

:::{dropdown} The *translated* protein for the acetylcholine receptor alpha-1 subunit (length 483 characters)

:::

***Q: Genes are comprised of DNA molecules. How many DNA comprise the gene for the acetylcholine receptor alpha-1 subunit***

***Q: How many unique DNA molecules are used for gene sequences? What are the single-letter codes for each?***

***Q: mRNA is comprised of RNA molecules. How many RNA comprise the mRNA for the acetylcholine receptor alpha-1 subunit?***

***Q: mRNA is build based on the DNA sequence. How does the mRNA sequence relate to the DNA sequence?***

***Q: Protein is comprised of AA molecules. How many AA comprise the protein for the acetylcholine receptor alpha-1 subunit?***

***Q: If genes "code for" protein structure, how many DNA molecules are used to determine each AA molecule?***

***Q: ***


## Genetic differences




***Q: Do all somatic cells (cells of the body tissues) have the same genome?***

***Q: Do all somatic cells have the same protein composition?***

***Q: ***

:::{figure-md} young-1999-genes
:class: figure

<img src="/images/Young1999-AVPgene-comparison.png" alt="fishy" width="500px">

"Structure of the V1a-receptor gene in voles. V1a-receptor genes from
montane vole (M. mon) and prairie vole (M. och) were isolated from genomic DNA
libraries. Transcription begins at +1 and polyadenylation (pA) occurs at +1,623 of
the prairie vole gene. The boxed area within these sites represents the coding
region and the vertical bars in the coding region represent the location of the
transmembrane domains. Two distinct loci were isolated from prairie vole DNA.
The sequences of the genomic clones have been deposited in GenBank
(accession number AF069304)."[^Young1999]
:::

[^Young1999]: Young, L., Nilsen, R., Waymire, K. et al. [Increased affiliative response to vasopressin in mice expressing the V1a receptor from a monogamous vole](https://doi.org/10.1038/23475). Nature 400, 766â€“768 (1999). 

Young et al 1999 [^Young1999] found different patterns of V1a-receptor binding in the brains of the nonmonogamous montane vole, and the monogamous prairie vole. They did not find differences in the protein sequence of the V1a receptor.
